title: windrush compensation scheme priti patel home office immigration
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Home secretary insists&nbspdelays occur&nbspbecause each case is&nbsphandled in ‘sensitive way’Priti Patel has admitted the Windrush compensation scheme has been too slow to reimburse people affected by the scandal – but said she would not apologise for waits of more than a year because cases are being handled in a “sensitive way”.Last month, the Home Office revealed its Windrush Compensation Scheme, which was announced in April 2019 and was estimated to pay out between £200m and £500m, had only provided compensation to 60 victims of the government’s actions.Speaking in the Commons on Tuesday, the home secretary said internal figures showed that over £1m has been offered to applicants of the scheme, and that once the offers were accepted by the applicants, payments would be made.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesShe said her department was dealing with “complicated cases” and that delays were occurring because each case was being handled in a “sensitive way”.In response to accusations made by Nick Thomas-Symonds, the shadow home secretary  that progress on compensating people affected had been “too slow”, Ms Patel said: “I agree, the way in which payments have been made have been far too slow. I’m not apologising for that at all.‘Grave risk’ of Windrush-style scandal again unless Home Office actsWatchdog to review hostile environment policy in light of Windrush “It is right that we treat each inidual with the respect and dignity they deserve. These are complicated cases.”The home secretary also announced that her department would accept the recommendations of the review into the Windrush scandal – published in March – in full.“The review itself is damning of the conduct of the Home Office and unequivocal about the ignorance and institutional thoughtlessness towards the race and the history of the Windrush generation by the department,” she said.“There are serious and significant lessons for the Home Office to learn.”During the sitting, Labour MP and chair of the Home Affairs Select Committee Yvette Cooper raised the cases of two men who were told in January that their cases were nearly finalised, but had made no progress since.One of these iniduals was Anthony Williams, who served in the armed forces for 13 years, and the other Andrew Bynoe, who was made homeless due to issues with his immigration status.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive updates on politics every morning by emailMs Cooper added: “Would she accept that keeping people in hardship and in limbo waiting like this compounds the justice that they have already felt?”Windrush report findsThe home secretary responded by saying that where iniduals were waiting for final settlements, they could access assistance through the vulnerable persons team, a separate scheme designed to provide help and advice where vulnerability issues are identified.It comes after the Home Office was warned there is a “grave risk” of a Windrush-style scandal happening again if ministers failed to implement the recommendations set out in the lessons learnt review into what led to the fiasco.In an interview with Radio 4’s Westminster Hour on Sunday, Wendy Williams, who wrote the review into the scandal, added that the compensation scheme for victims “is not demonstrating the benefits that it should”.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: egypt libya conflict border latest news turkey gaddafi
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Heart of the conflict in Libya moves to Sirte –&nbsphometown of former dictator Muammer Gaddafi&nbsp– as Borzou Daragahi reportsThe ongoing war in Libya appeared as if it were heading towards a direct confrontation between regional powers Turkey and Egypt over control of the hometown of former leader Muammar Gaddafi.Over the weekend, Egypt’s president Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, a backer of eastern Libyan warlord Khalifa Haftar, threatened to deploy troops to halt an advance by fighters loyal to the internationally recognised Government of National Accord (GNA) in Tripoli on the coastal city of Sirte as well as a key airbase in the southern town of Jufrah. “The preparedness to fight has become inevitable and necessary amid the prevailing instability and turmoil in our region,” Mr Sisi said in a speech to military officials. Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe GNA, backed militarily by Turkey, called Mr Sisi’s threat a “declaration of war,” and refused to halt its offensive. “We reject this, condemn it and consider it an act of aggression, a blatant intervention, which amounts to a declaration of war,” the GNA said in a letter on Sunday.The Arab League is scheduled to discuss the confrontation in Libya during an emergency session on Tuesday, but Tripoli is boycotting.  Libyan civilians are trapped in the crossfire of Haftar’s proxy warLibya’s general Haftar swindled out of millions by western mercenariesLibya has a chance at peace but Russia and the US are in the wayDanger of ‘miscalculation’ as powers scramble for position in LibyaFears of revenge attacks as Haftar’s forces flee Libya stronghold“We urge parties to commit to a ceasefire and resume negotiations immediately,” the US Embassy declared in a tweet, but efforts at diplomacy appeared to be failing. Turkey and its allies appear confident of a win and in no mood for a deal, and Mr Haftar and his supporters abroad, humiliated after weeks of battlefield losses, are reluctant to give any concessions from a position of weakness. “The Turks had a point,” said one western diplomat involved in Libya affairs. “They had to establish deterrence. Now they are acknowledging that they want to take control of the whole territory. They are saying Haftar has to go.”Libya’s civil war has been deadly, disruptive and gruesome. Hundreds of thousands have been displaced and hundreds killed. Last week came the discovery of mass graves filled with scores of bodies in the city of Tarhouna, where a militia loyal to Mr Haftar was pushed out last month by GNA forces.“Civilians in Libya continue to suffer disproportionately,” Stephanie Williams, the acting UN envoy to Libya, said last week in a presentation. “One million people are now in need of some form of humanitarian assistance.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailSirte, a city of some 50,000 people, is significant as the last major urban cluster before a set of crucial Libyan oil facilities and depots located on Libya’s eastern Mediterranean shore and controlled for now by forces loyal to Mr Haftar. It is home to a local population filled with supporters of Gaddafi who are allied with Mr Haftar and remain intensely hostile to the Islamist-tinged government in Tripoli.  It was controlled by militias loyal to the GNA until earlier this year, and both Ankara and the Tripoli government have said they would halt their offensive and be open to peace talks once it and Jufrah are under their control.Egypt boasts significant air and ground forces which could boost Mr Haftar in the battlefield and challenge any forces Turkey and the GNA could muster. But Marsa Matrouh, the last city at the Egyptian border where its troops are garrisoned, is some 15 hours away from Sirte. Meanwhile, Turks and allied GNA militias have a strong presence in Misurata, which lies less than three hours from Sirte, and Ankara has been flooding western Libya with military material and personnel for months. “Egypt’s political will to enter a physical contest with the Turkish-backed GNA coalition is not big,” said Jalel Harchaoui, a North Africa specialist at the Clingendael Institute in the Netherlands. “Turkey and the GNA forces are ready to move forcefully into both Sirte and Jufrah any day now.”Mr Sisi has appeared disappointed in Mr Haftar’s failures but is also under pressure from financial backers in the UAE and Saudi Arabia, who are hostile to the GNA’s inclusion of populist Islamist factions and see Turkey as a strategic threat. Egypt also views events in Libya with grave concern, worried troubles could spill over into its borders.“I believe the assertive language is serious and could lead to some form of action or military deployment even if largely symbolic,” said one Egyptian military analyst. “It appears Egypt’s intent is to force ceasefire negotiations by acting as counterbalance to Turkish and GNA strength on the ground.”The conflict in Libya has drawn in various international powers and their local backers. On the one side is Mr Haftar, the eastern commander and former CIA asset who is supported by the United Arab Emirates, Egypt, Russia and France. On the other side is the GNA in Tripoli, which in addition to Ankara has begun to receive the implicit blessing of Italy, Germany and the UK.Backed by UAE air power and Russian and Sudanese mercenaries, Mr Haftar launched an ill-fated offensive to take control of Tripoli last year. All of his gains were wiped out in a few extraordinary weeks after Turkey forcefully intervened, dispatching drones, anti-aircraft machinery, military personnel, and Syrian mercenaries to back the GNA forces. After initially supporting Mr Haftar, the White House under President Donald Trump appears to have settled into indifference. On Monday, GNA Prime Minister Fayez Serraj and high-profile interior minister Fathi Bashagha reportedly received a delegation of US military commanders from Africom, the US military force in Africa, amid concern about the deployment of Russian fighter jets in Jufrah. “I  don’t think the Trump administration is willing to be associated with someone who’s losing and also a war criminal,” Mohammed Ali Abdallah, a GNA envoy to the US, said in an interview.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: coronavirus cases second wave iran middle east
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.And which countries are yet to even reach the peak?The Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.Coronavirus lockdowns are lifting around the world, raising concerns that it could trigger a new wave of infections.Some countries that experienced a significant drop in new Covid-19 cases in April and May are now beginning to experience an uptick in confirmed daily cases.The concerning trend can be seen in several countries throughout the Middle East, most notably in Iran where new cases briefly dropped below 1,000 in early May but have now more than doubled.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesIran was one of the first countries to experience a significant outbreak of the deadly virus, with close to 200,000 total cases recorded.Looking at a smoothed seven-day rolling average for new daily cases, Iran's second wave came almost exactly one month after the first wave.The data suggests that Iran may have already reached the peak of its second wave and is now on the decline.Other countries in the region appear to be experiencing a more gradual second wave, with official figures from Israel revealing that new coronavirus cases have been rising consistently for the past three weeks.Israel's second wave remains a long way off the peak of the first wave, and the country remains one of the least affected in the Middle East.In Saudi Arabia, new cases are rising at record rates despite briefly appearing to peak in late May.The false peak means the latest surge of new cases could be counted as a continuation of the first wave, rather than a new second wave.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailTurkey is second only to Iran in terms of total coronavirus cases in the Middle East, and is also beginning to show early signs of a second wave of infections.Recent online search trends in the United States have hinted that a second wave may be on its way, however there is yet to be a sustained drop in new cases since a massive increase in March and April.With more than 2.1 million confirmed cases, the US is by far the worst affected country in the world and has not dropped below 20,000 new daily cases since 1 April.The United Kingdom was briefly the second worst hit country globally but has seen a consistent fall in new cases throughout May and June.With more than 1,000 new confirmed cases each day it continues to be the worst affected country in Europe.Most worryingly of all are the countries that continue to see the number of new cases climb each day.India has seen the number of new cases of Covid-19 rise nearly every day since the virus first came to the country in March, with more than 10,000 cases now recorded each day.A similar situation can be seen in Mexico, where the peak of the first wave appears to not yet have been reached.A new outbreak also appears to be taking hold in Beijing, though official figures from the Chinese capital suggest that it is still relatively small. title: remember saying have best cops
story: Well, yes, sonny, it still applies to the mugs in the street but not to an anarchic mob that decides it wants to chuck a statue of a long-dead slave trader into the briny or go shopping at Primark.Pity the poor rank-and-file ­copper.Our police are forced to jump to the tune of painfully woke senior officers and witless politicians making it all up as they go along.One moment cops are shouting warnings at nubile sunbathers in bikinis about the dire threat they pose to the nation’s health and the next those same coppers are required to stand meekly by while a crowd attempts to desecrate Churchill’s statue, or face drunken far-right thugs chucking bottles in their faces.The frontline copper is just obeying orders, of course. They do what they are told to by top brass but these horribly mixed messages are not a good look.It was once commonplace to hear that this country has the best police force in the world. When was the last time you heard that But it was true. Think of the late PC Keith Palmer, who died in  while heroically preventing a kne-wielding Islamist terrorist from entering the Palace of ­Westminster.Yet during this lockdown, there has been a steady draining away of respect for the police.How we all chortled to learn that in Hampshire,  per cent of police are now overweight or obese — the fat-buttocked blue line.While in London, when a ­protester leapt in front of the PM’s car causing a minor crash, it was hardly a complete surprise to see day-dreaming officers gormlessly staring off into space, as oblivious as Keystone Cops in a coma.There is a growing lack of respect for the police and that is the reason why  officers were injured in one weekend.The ordinary copper has been poorly led, leading to inevitable inaction the moment they are met by protesters or a crowd of eager shoppers at Nike Town.Their own senior officers seem far more concerned about ­displaying their politically correct credentials rather than anything resembling law and order. More than  years ago, the Macpherson Report into the death of Stephen Lawrence in South East London found the Met Police to be ­“institutionally racist”.There has been a great overhaul in the force since.It is hugely welcome that there are Black Asian and Minority ­Ethnicofficers now in senior Scotland Yard roles. This was long overdue.But there is still a long way to go before the force can be regarded as being truly erse.Five of the nation’s police forces have only one black officer.Forces in Durham, North ­Yorkshire, Warwickshire, Dyfed-Powys and North Wales had only one black officer in their ranks each as of March last year.This doesn’t mean our officers should be drawn into events like the death of George Floyd , miles away.It should be self-evident that British police were not in any way responsible for that death in Minneapolis.And yet a statement issued on behalf of Britain’s Chief Constables solemnly stated: “We stand alongside all those across the globe who are appalled and ­horried by the way George Floyd lost his le.“Justice and accountability should follow. We will tackle bias, racism or discrimination wherever we find it.”But the appalling racist violence of American cops — or indeed, when the police go on a violent rampage in Paris or Hong Kong — should not be clumsily confused with the issues our bobbies face here.As the violent clashes of the past few weeks have demonstrated, our officers should be focused on our own problems dealing with crime on our own streets.PAMELA ANDERSON ­promotes fake leather vegan handbags.You would never guess it’s mostly plastic.The bag, I mean. Not Pam.“Is Dad a James Bond fan by any chance ” cooed Britt on the website Cameo. “I’m here to fulfil your wildest desires.”Wow – you’ve got one old dad going now, Britt!You couldn’t get me a signed photo of Ana de Armas, could you AND they’re off!” cried Lizzie Cundy. No, not her clothes – the horses.“Doing this year’s Ascot at home,” sighs Lizzie.Just as well. They would never have let her into the Royal Enclosure carrying that glass of champagne.SIR KEIR STARMER, Labour’s gutless leader, is scared ­witless of upsetting his union paymasters so he can’t bring himself to admit that opening our schools is safe – despite sending his own children to school throughout the lockdown.Same old Labour – always hypocrites when it comes to educating their children. story: Military commanders for the Indian and Chinese armies have agreed to disengage troops from the Ladakh region of the Western Himalayas, after  soldiers brawled in a ferocious territorial battle.Soldiers fought with rocks, metal rods and wooden clubs at the Galwan Valley last Monday after a weeks-long standoff.China has not disclosed how many casualties it suffered, after the bloody skrimish left  Indian soldiers dead.An Indian minister also said around  Chinese soldiers may have been killed.On Tuesday, an Indian government source told Reuters that senior officials from both sides met for several hours on Monday.The met in a last minute attempt to reduce the tensions over the decades-long border row in the Galwan Valley high in the mountain range.The source said: “Modalities for disengagement from all friction areas in Eastern Ladakh were discussed and will be taken forward by both the sides,” the source said.Bloody violence has erupted between the two nuclear-armed states for years over the heavily contested border region.Both sides claim ownership of the region and stationed troops on either side of the so-called Line of Actual Control , the defacto border between the two nations.Each nuclear nation has blamed the other for the violence, which left the world waiting for talks to play out to avoid World War .China has laid claim to the entire Galwan Valley, saying the whole area is located on their side of the LAC.Foreign ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian said: Right and wrong is very clear and the responsibility entirely lies with the Indian side.India has dismissed Chinas claim over the valley as exaggerated and untenable - and said it goes against talks held between the two sides held before the clash.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris lockdown end what it means
story: This means from July  Brits will be able to head to the pub, restaurants, hairdressers and get married again.Most places will be able to reopen from next Saturday and the PM announced the  metre social distancing rule has been changed to one metre plus. This means people should try and keep  metres apart, but where they cannot they should take care to use other measures - such as face masks - to lower the risk of catch and spreading coronavirus. In restaurants this will mean making sure tables are back-to-back or even have screens between them. From next Saturday Brits will be able to go out for dinner or go to the pub. But crucially people can only go with one other householdsitting indoors - it doesnt have to be same one every time - but groups shouldnt include more than two household groups. Pubs will only be allowed to provide table service so there will be no crowding around the bar waiting to order a pint. Numbers in venues will also be limited. People are now allowed to go one anothers homes but there can only be one household at a time indoors. There are no limits on the number of people allowed indoors as long as people socially distance, and dont touch - that means no hugging. People dont have to stick to one household to visit either - but they wont be able to do it at the same time. It means families wont have to choose between dferent sets of grandparents - they just wont be able to see them at the same time. Friends and families can also stay overnight as long as theres only one other household. When heading out to a restaurant or pub people will have to give businesses their details. If there is an outbreak, this will enable contact tracers to follow up easily with anyone who may have been in contact with an infected person. Hotels, BBs, holiday lettings and campsites will be allowed to reopen on July th meaning people will be able to spend the first night out of their home for the first time since lockdown. People with second homes will also be allowed to use those. People in England can holiday with one other household as long as social distancing is followed. Hairdressers will also be allowed to reopen and fix many of the DIY hair cuts people resorted to during lockdown. title: blue green algae infects lake district
story: Sunshine-loving blue-green algae has infected Windermere, Derwentwater, Ullswater and Coniston Water.It is potentially fatal to pets, wild animals and livestock and can make people sick or suffer painful skin rashes.Steve Gaskell, of the Lake District National Park Authority, said shoreline owners were advised to put up signs.The EA has received reports of possible blue-green algae in both Windermere and Coniston.We adviseyou come into contact with the water, wash in clean water.Andyou feel ill, contact your doctor or nearest hospital.It can be fatal for pets and we would advise pets are kept away from the water.The LDNPA says it is not possible to tellblooms of blue-green algae are toxic just by looking at them, so it is best to assume they are.The algae, called cyanobacteria, naturally occurs in inland waters, estuaries and the sea.But deadly toxic blooms can form in hot and sunny conditions.People who have swam through or swallowed the algae can suffer from skin rashes, eye irritation, vomiting, diarrhoea, fever and muscle and joint pain.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: opening pubs but not schools doesnt add up
story: PRAISE the Lord – the decision is made. You can now at last be within ft in of someone outside your immediate household! What’s more, from July , you will be able to eat in restaurants, have a drink and, of course, continue shopping.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesWhat you won’t be able to do, unless you are very fortunate, is to get your children into school, which says something about our national priorities. Make no mistake about it, this is a “national emergency”. Education should have the upfront priority that we rightly give the NHS and saving our economy. The failure since the beginning of March to plan ahead for getting all schools and all youngsters back into the classroom has been reprehensible.I say all schools because the majority have been open for the children of key workers and for children designated as vulnerable.Many teachers have been doing a first-class job trying to keep in touch with children at home, providing them with online tuition, homework and marking. But there is still time to mobilise all the necessary resources to make it possible to get children back to school for at least a couple of weeks before the end of this term.Yes, it would involve finding extra premises for schools with inadequate space. Yes, we would have to appeal to teachers who have recently retired to come back for perhaps a few hours a week. Yes, we would need to employ supply teachers.In addition we could use university students, who won’t be finding summer jobs any time soon, to assist.Of course, we don’t have that reliable summer weather that will allow teaching outside on a regular basis, butDenmark can place many lessons in an outside setting, we can.If the French, Lord help us, can get their schools mobilised and back to full operation, we can. Their trade unions are far more bolshy than ours, and teachers regrettably much less well paid.So we need a combination of creativity, imagination and drive to get pupils back. We need to rebuild the confidence of parents and staff that they are highly unlikely to contract the virus from the children, or of the children passing it on to each other.That way, we can have ironed out the glitches and be ready in September to be absolutely on the ball. Small group tutoring for recovery programmes, mentoring not just organised centrally, but co-ordinated locally.For anyone who doesn’t believe that two or three weeks matter in terms of education, when children have been out of school since the middle of March, then think again. This is about equality, narrowing the gap between the haves and have-nots, and opening a window on the world. But it is also more than that. It’s a place of social interaction, of well-being and of safety. Don’t take my word for it. Take the word of the Royal College of Paediatricians, the people whose whole le is spent on the well-being of children. They are very clear: Schools must , children need each other as well as their teachers.The recognition of the importance of schools was something I was proud to oversee in , when the incoming government’s priority slogan was, “education, education, education”.Don’t get me wrong. The belated announcement last week of a one per cent uplt for all schools and a £million pot for an online recovery programme is extremely welcome. A pity, therefore, that in making a really great announcement, the Government managed not to put any money aside for the  to -year-olds in further education, who are surely the target group we would want to be helping the most.So, thank you to all those who have done everything they can to keep the wheels on the cart over the past dficult three and a half months. But now we need both national leadership and local organisation. To use an old adage, we need to think national but we need to act local. Education trusts, local authorities, teachers’ unions and all those committed to the future of this nation should want to come together to make it work.In the next ten days, while the Government thinks about its advice, others can get on with the job. Take what is working best and spread it.What can work in France or Denmark or Germany can certainly work here. We are not out of the woods yet, but we can take logical, rational and brave decisions. That is what leadership is all about.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast brits heatwave june day
story: Temperatures are tipped to rocket towards C tomorrow as the country continues to bask in a summer heatwave.Thursday could set a new record above the hottest June day ever when temperatures hit .C in .It would also beat last years hottest June day when highs of around C were recorded at Heathrow, West London, on June .The hottest day of the year so far was .C in May, but todays temperatures are due to soar past that and hit C before climbing even higher on Thursday.Met Office forecaster Luke Miall said: Thursday will probably be the hottest day in the region of  or  degrees.Across the UK, sunseekers have flocked to beaches and parks to soak up the summer rays this week.Brits cooled off with a pint of beer or a dip in the sea as the hot weather continued.England and Wales will stay warm this evening but could and occasional rain could hit northern and western Scotland and parts of Northern Ireland.The UKs balmy weather is likely to lessen by the weekend, with fresher air cooling the country down.The hot spell has sparked concerns about wildfires and the wellbeing of elderly residents cooped up indoors during the UKs coronavirus lockdown.And the Met Office has warned sunseekers to take care while outdoors in the next few days.The National Fire Chiefs Councilhas warned against starting campfires which can easily get out of control.The NFCC said: The weather is forecast to improve and, although weve had our fair share of rain recently, the risk of wildfires remains.These fires are often preventable, soyou are enjoying the countryside please be wildfire-aware and look out for our advice.People with elderly relatives should make sure they keep cool during the lockdown, Age UK has warned.The sizzling conditions are due to air arriving from the Atlantic and warming up as it moves across the UK.But there could be an increased risk of storms by the end of the week.Deputy Chief Meteorologist, Matthew Lehnert, said: We’re also seeing an increased risk of thunderstorms towards the end of the week which is expected to bring an end to the very warm and sunny weather.Meanwhile, firefighters have called for disposable barbecues to be banned due to fears they could spark grass fires.The London Fire Brigade has had to battle more than , grass fires across the city so far this year.The Brigades Deputy Commissioner Richard Mills said barbecuing on dry grass was thoughtless and reckless.We understand a barbecue ban can be hard to enforce and many councils already have one in place, but we need our partners to do whatever they can to help us protect our city’s open spaces from devastating blazes, he said.There is likely to be a prolonged spell of hot weather and for the sake of our city and of our firefighters – who have to work in sweltering temperatures to tackle these blazes – it’s time people listened to our warnings.“All it takes is one inconsiderate act and a huge area of grass can go up in minutes.”Brits have also been warned not to leave bottles of hand sanitiser in hot cars as they could catch fire.The NHS has issued the warning as the heatwave sends temperatures skyrocketing.NHS staff have been told to remove all bottles of alcohol-based hand sanitiser used in the fight against coronavirus from their cars after fires broke out.The warm weather can cause the alcohol in the hand sanitiser to evaporate, with flammable vapours being released.The vapour can then ignite and cause dangerous fires inside cars.Pressure can also build up inside the bottle, forcing them to rupture and explode.Our journalists strive for title: harry shaped hole happy royal family
story: To the rest of us, it’s a charming exception to the more formal royal photos of old.But how was it received by the person who’s so obviously missing from this image of paternal closeness . . .  Prince Harry Since a spokesman confirmed that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex would be inactive on their @sussexroyal Instagram account from Aprilthere’s no way of knowing whether Harry would have publicly thanked his father last Sunday or , indeed, he has done so in private.But given that he’s reportedly homesick for the UK, this photo — taken in December — must have prompted a visceral longing for home. How could it not The sense of countryside and fresh air it evokes, the tweed caps, the fingerless mittens, the ornate walking stick . . .  just the innate Britishness of it all. Such a far cry from the smog, red carpets, bling and supercars of LA.And then, of course, it’s a reminder of the people he’s known since birth.Those who, unlike the “mwah mwah”, showbiz crowd, love him for who, rather than what, he is.Whichever way you view his behaviour of late, it’s undeniable that there is a huge, Harry-shaped hole in this image of family togetherness.Of course, there are Zoom meetings to be had and, post-lockdown, the occasional visit to be made. But it’s never quite the same.And therein lies the rub when you marry someone from another country.At first your initial attraction and then love for each other transcends geographical or cultural dferences.But when children come along and you’re required to stay in one place, inevitably one of you has to give up more than the other.Meghan tried it, albeit for a very short time, and now Harry is the one living thousands of miles away from his family and the only le he’s ever known.He made the decision to step down as a senior royal and decamp to the US for the sake of his new family — Meghan and Archie — but that doesn’t make it any less tough to see the old one ticking over nicely without him.A couple of years ago, I was in a central London restaurant with a group of other married couples and, much to the annoyance of we wives, the husbands couldn’t take their eyes off a woman sitting at the bar.Wearing the shortest of dresses, her legs were encircled around the object of her affections and her tongue made frequent visits to his ear.I recognised the man as actor Stephen Campbell Moore, ex-husband of The Crown star Claire Foy, and his obviously smitten companion as Sophie Cookson, who played Christine Keeler in last year’s BBC drama about the Profumo scandal.Fast forward to lockdown and this photo, suggests the couple may now be expecting their first child.The fond arrival of which will mean a heavy-hearted goodbye to those late-night, lust-filled liaisons that had the rest of us drooling with envy.Kaiser Chiefs frontman Ricky Wilson says he amuses himself by lying in interviews then changing his Wikipedia page to match his inventions.It reminds me of my stint as a royal correspondent when, after days of being on the road together, we would challenge each other to use silly names in stories.Hence, “Toby Lerone” was quoted in an article filed from the royals’ favourite ski resort in Switzerland, and in another story to do with Italy, “Sam Buca” made an appearance.Daft, I know, but it amused usno one .Mr Pendragon, who refuses to pay to park, says they stopped him from leaving his car on nearby roads.Shouldn’t he have been on horseback Bored by St Tropez, billionaires are reportedly snapping up “expedition yachts” that will take them to more adventurous corners of the globe.The one owned by US billionaire Ray Dalio has three deep-ing submersibles, and converted former Soviet spy boat Olivia is currently on the market for £million.Back home, lock-down quarantine rules have forced a  per cent rise in multi-millionaire Brits splashing their cash on vast private pools.Meanwhile, the rest of us will make do with a boat in the bath and a paddling pool.Sarah Ferguson – aka Prince Andrew’s ex we – is building up quite a following on her YouTube channel, where she reads children’s books such as The Wonky Donkey and Little Red Riding Hood while wearing fancy dress.Her success is no surprise, because on the many occasions I’ve seen her at charity events, she always connects brilliantly with the children in attendance.But personally, I can’t wait for her to get round to the critically acclaimed Idan Hadari book about a boy who wants to be famous.It’s called Andrew’s Claim To Fame.Or, in the Duke of York’s case, should that be infamy Yep. She now looks about .When -year-old Khairi Saadallah started his alleged kne rampage in a Reading park, a young, off-duty police officer ran towards the danger and rugby tackled him to the ground.It was a selfless act of bravery that, according to sources, saved “many more people dying”.Meanwhile, a judge has praised the bravery of PC Andrew Harper, who died after being dragged along by a car as he chased some thieves.Both of these are salutary reminders that, while every police force in the world has a few bad apples, the majority of those working in law enforcement are undeniably courageous people doing a tough job that most of us would shy away from.The latest money-making exercise candle from Gwyneth Paltrow is called This Smells Like My Orgasm.Which, as you ask, is “tart grapefruit, neroli, and ripe cassis berries blended with gunpowder tea and Turkish rose absolutes”. Er, right.Like its highly successful predecessor This Smells Like My Vagina candle – which, for the blissfully unaware, is “geranium, citrusy bergamot, and cedar absolutes juxtaposed with Damask rose and ambrette seed” – it costs£.Clearly, she’s a sales genius who could flog underwear to a nudist, but one suspects any attempt to branch out with a, to put it politely, Smells Like My Winkle range might prove a tougher sell.Hmmm. While the new name — Lost The Pot Noodle — is inspired, one notes that it now requires the consumer to put the ingredients in a mug or make it in a pan on the stove.As any self-respecting, Olympically idle student will tell you, a clean mug is a rarer sighting than an eclipse and, as for a pan, eventhey own one it will be housing enough penicillin growth to solve America’s recent shortage.So, memo to Unilever: Don’t phase out the original just yet.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: McClain suffered a fatal heart attack as a result of the Aurora encounter. He was pronounced dead on August , .Elijah McClain was a young black man who grew up in Aurora, Colorado.He was put in a chokehold by authorities and suffered a heart attack as a result of the encounter in .His death was similar to that of George Floyd, who prosecutors say was suffocated by a Minneapolis police officer on Memorial Day.McClains case has not received extensive media coverage but the Black Lives Matter movement is demanding justice.The hashtag #JusticeforElijahMcClain is circulating on Twitter, calling for a re-investigation into the case.According to Twitter, McClain was a soft, introverted soul who played violin for kittens.Elijah McClain was walking home from a local convenience store on August , , after picking up some tea.According to McClains family, the -year-old was anemic and preferred to wear a ski mask to keep his face warm while he was walking.The Aurora Police Department received a call from a civilian about a suspicious man walking around. dispatched police officers who placed McClain in a chokehold upon their arrival to the scene.According to reports, McClain repeatedly said he could not breathe, much like the George Floyd case.In bodycam footage obtained by McClains family, an officer reportedly threatens him for struggling.He is laying on the ground vomiting, he is begging, he is saying, I cant breathe, described Mari Newman, the McClain family lawyer.One of the officers says, Dont move again. If you move again, Im calling in a dog to bite you.Twitter users claim Elijahs last words were: I’m an introvert. I’m just dferent that’s all. I’m so sorry. I don’t have a gun. I don’t do that stuff.All I was trying to do was become better. I’ll do it...You all are phenomenal.You are beautul. And I love you. Try to forgive me. I’m sorry.When paramedics arrived, they reportedly administered a dose of ketamine to sedate McClain and calm his anxiety.The drug caused the young man to go into cardiac arrest on his way to the hospital.He fell into a coma, and three days later, he was pronounced dead.At the time of McClains death, Denver  News stated, ...they couldn’t determine whether McClains death was an accident, was due to natural causes, or is a homicide related to the police departments use of a carotid hold.The officers on the scene were placed on temporary leave.They are back in the field with no charges.There is currently a petition circulating on Change.org demanding that the officers involved in Elijahs death be taken off duty and that the investigation be re-opened.The petition has currently garnered .million signatures and is calling for million in total.You can sign the Justice for Elijah McClain petition here.Black Lives Matter is a movement fighting police brutality and racial injustice in the US.The organization launched after the fatal shooting of Trayvon Martin in  - and George Zimmermans subsequent acquittal.Over the years, it has championed equal rights for African Americans, particularly in the justice system.The movement recently resurged after the death of George Floyd at the hands of police officers in Minnesota.Donald Trump called the group isive when he was running for president in .There are a number of organizations you can support to aide the Black Lives Matter movement.You can donate straight to Black Lives Matter on the BLM website - but there are other causes that help fight the injustice.A GoFundMe page for Floyd has already raised a staggering million.The Minnesota Freedom Fund fights back against the states unfair bail system.The Bail Project helps people post bail who cannot afford it.Black Visions Collective believes in a future where all Black people have autonomy, safety is community-led, and we are in right relationship within our ecosystems.Donations to Reclaim the Block will help keep communities in Minneapolis safe.The Atlanta Solidarity Fund helps people who get arrested during protests.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: swim england pubs pools coronavirus lockdown easing
story: Sports centres and gyms were dealt a blow yesterday as the Government said they still pose too much of a risk to coronavirus spreading.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe PM has slashed the m rule, allowed sleepovers and pubs to reopen from next Saturday.Hotels, pubs, libraries, hairdressers and even caravan sites will be able to open from July - but you can only use them with one other household.But gyms, sports centres and swimming pools must remain shut and recreational cricket, football and rugby remain banned.Sports leaders expressed their frustration at the decision to keep facillities closed.“Many will fail to understand how pubs, restaurants, cinemas, museums and hair salons have been given the go-ahead to open on July  but not chlorine-filled swimming pools,” Jane Nickerson, chief executive of Swim England told The Times. “It appears that it is OK to sit on the couch watching professional sport, go out for a high-calorie meal and then go to the pub but you can’t go for a swim, which provides a sanitised environment.”PureGym also attacked the illogical and short-sighted decision to keep gyms closed.“We understand that these decisions are not easy, but it is a strange ‘war on obesity’ that sees pubs and restaurants open before gyms,” PureGym said in a statement. “Our facilities are, on average, the size of five or six doubles tennis courts and are exceptionally well ventilated, enabling people to work and exercise safely and securely.”On Tuesday, the PM admitted he would love to play village cricket again and regretted that not all venues would be allowed to restart.Former England cricket captain Michael Vaughan suggested amateur cricketers should defy the lockdown.“Natural vector of the disease  What a load of utter b******, he tweeted.Hand sanitiser in every player’s pocket, use every time you touch the ball, simple. Recreational cricket should just play from July .”The full list of businesses includes:Earlier this month, Swim England published a list of guidelines for swimmers called Returning To The Pool.Pools closed on March , along with gyms and other fitness centres as the country went into lockdown.Arriving ready to swim with costumes worn underneath clothes and showering before leaving home, again before entering the pool and then after swimming are some of the recommendations that have been made.Showers may be available at the facility but by arriving wearing your swimwear under your clothing and showering at home pre and post swimming you will help minimise time spent in the changing rooms, the guidelines read.Wide and slower strokes like butterfly should be avoided when lanes are busy, according to the recommendations.Swimmers should also move to the edge of their lane and keep their distance from others while resting.The rules could see a five-lane m pool with just three lanes in use to allow for social distancing.Swimmers would be asked to keep moving in a clock-wise direction in the lanes and lanes could be limited to around five people.Any equipment used in pools will need to be cleaned in between use, while capacity will need to be limited to allow each swimmer six square metres of space.During swimming lessons, teachers will need to stay outside the pool, and only one parent will be allowed to take a child to a lesson.Swimming in wild and open water is still allowed under lockdown rules, and many Brits have been making the most of the warmer weather to enjoy a dip in the ocean.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dozens primary pupils home child teacher positive coronavirus
story: Kids in a bubble at Shaw Ridge Primary in Swindon are isolating after two positive tests for the virus.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesSchool chiefs say a child in Year  and their teacher have coronavirus.All staff who have been in close contact with the infected teacher are also now self-isolating and waiting to be tested.As a result of the staff shortage, all Year  pupils have been told to stay at home for at least a week, or until teachers have been given their test results.In total, the school has  pupils aged between four and .The rest of the school is open for children of keyworkers, as well as those in nursery, Reception and Year .Headteacher Sally Cowell said in her email to parents: We are continuing to take all necessary steps as advised by Public Health England to ensure this does not spread further and all staff who have been in close contact with the infected staff member must be tested as a precautionary measure.Because of this, we do not have sufficient staff to maintain the Year  class bubbles and so we have taken the decision to close these bubbles, at least for the remainder of this week as we await staff test results.Parents have been informed and children have been collected.The rest of the school remains open for key workers children, nursery, Reception, and Year  children as per their rotas.The school will be sending further updates to parents.The news comes as Boris Johnson announced all children will be back in class by September.During a speech in Commons yesterday, he said there will be full attendance as the two-metre social distancing rule will be reduced to one-metre plus on July .The new rule allows Brits to get closer to one another - but only with mitigations like masks in place.But in the latest wrangle between the Government and teaching unions over the issue, Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said the plans for full schools are pure fantasy.It may be possible to accommodate more pupils in classrooms with a one-metre plus separation, but not all pupils, he said.There just isnt enough space in many classrooms to do this.It isnt a magic bullet.Schools, colleges and nurseries closed more than  weeks ago due to the Covid- outbreak, remaining open only for vulnerable youngsters and the children of key workers.Since then, officials have been locked into disputes with unions over when schools will reopen.Union bosses were last week accused by MPs of scaring parents by pushing the view that schools are death traps.A new study by Cambridge University found the risk to children is very low - and youngsters are more likely to be hit by lightning than die of coronavirus.A number of schools have faced cases of the virus since they began reopening.Last week, Joseph Locke Primary School in Barnsley closed its gates after three members of staff tested positive, while earlier this month, Rawlins Academy in Quorn, Leicester closed after a suspected case.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no football matched pub loud music ban coronavirus
story: Any entertainment which forces people to raise their voice and shout to be heard should not be allowed when pubs open their doors once again, fresh advice says.Buried in the Governments guidance on reopening pubs and restaurants, it says that certain steps should be considered to stop the spread of the virus and prevent pubs from becoming hotspots.This may include preventing entertainment, such as broadcasts, that is likely to encourage audience behaviours increasing transmission risk, it says.And other close contact activities like communal dancing will also be off the cards too.For example, loud background music, communal dancing, group singing or chanting.The guidance goes on to say: All venues should ensure that steps are taken to avoid people needing to unduly raise their voices to each other. This includes, but is not limited to, refraining from playing music orbroadcasts that may encourage shouting, includingplayed ata volume that makes normal conversation dficult. This is because of the potential for increased risk of transmission,particularly from aerosol transmission.The guidance means that music is likely to stay switched off in venues, while screening of football and other sport is likely to be banned.The guidance also contains reams of information for businesses so they can get ready to open their doors from July  - as Boris Johnson announced yesterday.The PM has also announced that social distancing will be cut from two metres to one metre from July  to give venues the chance to let more people in.Some of the rules included:Yesterday the PM announced that pubs, restaurants and hotels will be allowed to open from July .But gyms, nightclubs, nail salons and spas must remain closed for now as they still pose a risk to spread the virus.Ministers have said they aim to get gyms open by the middle of next month.THE following businesses are allowed to reopen from July , following the announcement from Boris Johnson today.However, the following businesses have been told they cannot open yet.The government will be reviewing lockdown restrictions for these establishments over the coming weeks.Businesses that cant reopen:To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chris evans black lives matter writing competition
story: The Virgin Radio Breakfast Show host urged young Brits to have their voice heard as part of the worlds largest story-writing competition.The Chris Evans  Words: Black Lives Matter competition is intended to encourage important conversations at home, at school and across the nation on the issues emerging from the movement.Chris is relaunching the contest this year after the Beeb unexpectedly canned the hugely successful event this month after ten years.The competition was created and launched by him in  when he was presenter of the Radio  Breakfast Show. He has teamed up with Michael Underwood and Angellica Bell – who are also on the judging , along with Malorie Blackman – to encourage children aged five to  to put their thoughts on the global conversation into words – but no more than .Entries can be in ious forms, including poetry, and should be drawn from the children’s own thoughts and experiences.Presenter-turned-teacher Michael, , says the best entry will win a “money-can’t-buy prize with lots of dferent elements” but it will certainly involve going behind the scenes of a top TV show.Plus, many of the top stories will be read out on Chris’s Virgin Radio show by special guests.The One Show host Angellica, , says: “We both started our careers in children’s TV and know first-hand how open and honest young people can be.“Giving them this  to express how they feel on the subject is essential and empowering.”The beloved competition has previously seen more than a million stories submitted on topics about everything from technology to climate change.The popular initiative encourages children to tap into their own creativity and imagination, using storytelling to share their experience and understanding of how dferent ethnicities and cultures interact.One hundred of the stories could even be collated as a book. The  Words team said: The narratives we write and share matter. We ask children to draw on their own experiences and feelings to create a story that can be as imaginative and visionary as they want. Storytelling is a must!It will be open from :am on Monday th June until Friday rd July at .pm .Four semi-finalists in teach age group will be chosen between July  and .The winner will be announced on Friday July .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: 13 ways pubs look different
story: News ways pubs will look dferent as loud music and football screenings are bannedNew coronavirus rules will cover pubs, bars and restaurants in England from July . Weve read through all of it - and it shows things are going to be very, very dferentShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsShouting and loud broadcasts or music will be banned - so no more of this " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailLoud football match screenings or music, dance floors, ketchup bottles and even sheltering from the rain are set to be banned when Englandaposs pubs reopen on July . Government guidance today shows many toilets will need to be one-in, one-out and bar staff hidden behind screens to prevent the spread of the virus. Pubs will be told to keep lists of everyone who comes in for  days in case there is an outbreak - with more outdoor seats and tape to mark distance on the floor. Bar managers will be told to work with their rivals on the same street to make sure they stagger their opening times. And punters will be warned they canapost shelter insidea rainstorm - otherwise they could cause an outbreak. We knew a lot of the restrictions already. For example, you can only sit indoors with one other household - socially distanced. If youaposre in the beer garden, you can sit in a group of up to six - socially distanced - or in a group of two households of any size. Now the governmentaposs guidance shows just how dferent the new normal will be to le before. Here are  key ways itaposll change your experience of the pub. . Loud music or broadcasts will be banned to stop people shouting  Loud music or loud broadcasts like football will be banned to stop people shouting at each other. The guidance says all venues should ensure that steps are taken to avoid people needing to unduly raise their voices to each other. This includes, but is not limited to, refraining from playing music or broadcasts that may encourage shouting, includingplayed at a volume that makes normal conversation dficult. This is because of the potential for increased risk of transmission, particularly from aerosol transmission. It also says loud background music, communal dancing, group singing or chanting should be prevented. . Live music and comedy will be banned  The guidance says venues should not permit live performances, including drama, comedy and music, to take place in front of a live audience. This is to stop aerosol transmission - from either the performer or their audience. Theatres are likewise allowed to open but onlythey donapost put on a live show. . Ketchup bottles and cutlery are banished from tables  The guidance says pubs and restaurants should provide cutlery and condiments only when food is served. And the days of the communal ketchup or mayonnaise bottle are numbered - as pubs and restaurants should provide only disposable condiments. Communal bottles are allowed but onlythey are cleaned after every single use. . Everyone has to give their name to staff - and itaposs kept for  days  All pubs, bars, restaurants and more are being told to assist with the NHS Test and Trace programme. That means keeping a temporary record of your customers and visitors for  days. The guidance doesnapost say how this should be done but lists visitor books or bookings records. Pubs will need to assist NHS Test and Trace with requests for that dataneeded in order to contain clusters or outbreaks. . Bar staff will stand behind screens  The guidance recommends using screens or barriers to separate workers from each other, and from customers at points of service. That could mean bar staff serving from behind a perspex screen to avoid transmission. Staff are also asked to use back-to-back or side-to-side working possible. And staff rotas will need to be redrawn so each person only has contact with a fixed number of others on their team. Tables will be spaced further apart and floor tape or paint will be used to mark areas to help people comply with social distancing. They should be two metres apart - or one metrethere is risk mitigation in place like screens, back-to-back seating or face coverings. . Some toilets will be one-in, one-out  The guidance recommends one way flow systems to stop people bunching up - such as using one door as an entry and one as an exit. Pubs should also arrange one-way travel routes between transport hubs and venues, it says. But thataposs a problem when it comes to pub toilets, many of which are cramped with narrow entrances. On toilets, the guidance urges pubs to use a limited entry approach, with one in, one out. . Youaposll get more outdoor seats, table service - and use apps to order your drinks  Pubs are being encouraged to put in more outdoor seats - with changes coming down the track to let them use car parks as beer gardens. Outdoor table service should also be encouraged, the guidance says - and table service should be followed as a rule to stop people queues. Where bar or counter service is unavoidable, people should be stopped from staying at the bar or counter after ordering, or leaning on it. Pubs are also told to encourage use of contactless ordering from tables where available - for example, through an ordering app. . Staff could radio food orders through to the kitchen Staff are told to reduce movement by discouraging non-essential trips within venues. That could mean restricting access to some areas, encouraging use of radios, telephones or other electronic devices when sending orders from service areas to kitchens, where permitted. The radios would have to be cleaned between use. . Youaposll be banned from propping up the bar - or sheltering from the rain  Pubs are warned they have to plan for keeping the -metre or aposone metre plusapos rules eventhere is a thunderstorm. They need to be clear that customers cannot seek shelter indoors unless social distancing can be maintained. . Indoor spaces will have to be massively below capacity  Sitting indoors will be allowed - but numbers are strictly limited. New coronavirus laws from July  in England will make it illegal for groups of more than  people to form, except for limited circumstances. That means pubs may have to lower capacity even further than it would bethey had all tables two metres apart. The guidance explains: Evenit is possible to safely seat a number of people inside a venue, it may not be safe for them all to travel or enter that venue. . Youaposll see this sign in the window  Pubs should work with their customers to tell them about the restrictions on gatherings. That means not gathering indoors with more than one other household. And it means not gathering outdoors with more than either one other household, or six people in total from any number of households. In , firms should also display a notication in a prominent place to show a risk assessment has been carried out and theyaposre following the rules. A picture of the notice is above. . Nearby pubs must work together to open at dferent times Inidual businesses should consider the cumulative impact of many venues re-opening in a small area. This means working with local authorities, neighbouring businesses and travel operators to assess this risk and applying additional mitigations. This might have to include staggering entry times with other venues and taking steps to avoid queues building up in surrounding areas.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBoris Johnson has today announced massive changes to the coronavirus lockdown in England. Pubs, hairdressers, hotels, campsites, restaurants, cinemas, museums and galleries can open bang on Saturday  July - despite fears itaposs too soon to unlock the nation, especially all at once. Two households will also be able to meet indoors and even stay overnight - as long as they maintain social distancing. And the two-metre social distancing rule will be cut down to a one metre plus rule, with people able to be closerthey sit side-by-side or wear a mask. The death toll of people with coronavirus in the UK today passed , and stands at ,. And scientists warn the risk of catching Covid- is ten times higher at m away than m away. Yet Boris Johnson told his Cabinet the changes were crucial to rescue the economy, which has plunged into recession thanks to the pandemic. He told Parliament: Our long national hibernation is beginning to come to an end.But the PM also warnedthe virus surges too soon, the nation will be forced back into lockdown potentially region by region. Todayaposs changes come after the PM held a crunch meeting with his two top scientic advisors last night. The trio will appear later today at the pm press conference to offer more explanation. Later we are expecting detailed guidance on exactly what pubs, hotels and other venues will have to look like when they reopen. But key venues including hostels, soft play areas, gyms, swimming pools and nightclubs all remain shut. So what exactly has the Prime Minister announced so far and how will it affect you  Hereaposs everything you need to know. Things you can do from July  Venues that CAN reopen in England from July  All these venues can reopen in England providing they can show they are aposCovid-secureapos:Hotels and BBs Holiday apartments or homes Cottages or bungalows Campsites Caravan parks Boarding houses Places of worship Libraries Community centres Restaurants, cafes and workplace canteens Bars Pubs Cinemas Bingo halls Theatres and concert halls - but on the basis it’s not a live performance. They can only screen past performances for example Museums and galleries Hair salons and barbers Outdoor playgrounds Outdoor gyms Funfairs Theme parks Adventure parks and activities Amusement arcades Other indoor leisure centres and facilities - including indoor gaming, social clubs, model villages, and indoor attractions at aquariums and zoos.You can finally visit friends and family indoors - but you canapost hug  People in England can have friends and family round to their house to eat, hang out and stay overnight from July  - but they can’t hug. For the first time since March, indoor gatherings will be allowed between two households who havenapost joined together in a “bubble”. Bubbles - a permanent joining of two households which let people break social distancing rules - aren’t being expanded, for now. But new rules will allow two households in England to meet indoors. This applies to all indoor gatherings, be they in private homes or in places like pubs. When you are indoors, your household will be able to meet with one other household at a time. That potentially includes staying over at someone’s house.  There is no limit on the size of either of the households which can meet. And unlike with bubbles, ’exclusivity’ is not required. So you can have one friend round for a meal one weekend and another friend round another weekend. But there’s a big catch - these households should continue to remain socially distant from one another when they meet, That means following the m or ‘m plus’ guidance, and also following other advice such as regular hand washing. You can meet more people outdoors  There will be a slight change to the rules for people meeting outdoors from July . Currently up to six people from up to six households can meet in a park or garden,they maintain social distancing. This will continue, but there will also now be another option. Two households of any size - for example, two families of four - will now also be allowed to meet outdoors, as long as they maintain social distancing. So you can either meet five friends from dferent households, or an unlimited number of friends from one household. The two-metre rule will be cut  Changes will be made to the -metre rule in England from July . Where it’s not possible to stay  metres apart, people will instead be advised to keep to a social distance of “one metre plus”. This means staying one metre apart - plus mitigations which reduce the risk of transmission. On public transport it means people stay one metre away but with a face covering. In other spaces it will likely mean having screens between tables, making sure people face away from each other, putting in hand washing facilities, minimising amount of time spent with people from dferent households., and being outdoors where possible. Government sources claim having such mitigations in place at one metre away can have a “broadly equivalent impact” on transmission as staying two metres apart. But it comes despite grave warnings of the danger of moving people closer together. Scientists say the risk of catching coronavirus from someone is  to  times higher at one metre away compared to two metres away. Yet now fewer people have coronavirus in society overall, the overall risk of catching it is lower. And Tory MPs and the pub trade have piled pressure on Boris Johnson to cut the distance to save the economy. Crucially, the review was led by No and while it took advice from scientists, they had no powers of veto. Economists also contributed to the review.  Pubs, bars, restaurants, cafes and workplace canteens can all reopen in England from July  - both indoor and outdoors. But thereaposs a catch -youaposre indoors, you can only meet with people from one other household. And you should still maintain social distancing rules. That means staying either two metres apart, or one metre apart with mitigation measuresyou canapost manage two metres. It means no propping up the bar or standing in groups, and pubs will be encouraged to have table service where possible. All venues - from pubs to places of worship - will be expected to keep a record of people who visit, to enable contact tracing. But landlords won’t be expected to police what household customers belong to, or check ID of everyone coming in. Guidance for pubs will be published later today. You can get a haircut - but canapost get your nails done  Hairdressers and barbers will be allowed to reopen in England from July  with protective measures - including face visors for those cutting hair. It means millions of Brits can finally get a haircut after more than three months of having their locks chopped at home. But nail salons, which involve people sitting face to face, will remain shut for the foreseeable. You can go on staycation to English hotels, BBs and campsites - but not hostels  Hotels, BBs, holiday apartments or homes, cottages or bungalows, campsites, caravan parks and boarding houses can all reopen to paying guests in England from July . Again, they must follow Covid-secure guidelines - but people will be able to stay overnight away from their home. Despite concerns over shared facilities, campsites will be able to reopen in England from July . This would include showers and washing-up blocks. There will be Covid-secure guidelines to minimise the spread of the virus. But hostels with shared bedrooms cannot yet. This is dferent to Wales which is keeping both campsites and hostels shut. You can go to visit cinemas, galleries and museums  The government has now officially set the date of Saturday  July for cinemas, galleries and museums to reopen in England. Guidance will be published shortly on how to keep them safe - including one-way systems, spaced queuing, increased ventilation, and pre-booked tickets. A No source said: We are only able to move forward this week because the vast majority of people have taken steps to control the virus. But the more we open up, the more important it is that everyone follows the social distancing guidelines. We will not hesitate to reverse these stepsit is necessary to stop the virus running out of control.  Today comes hot on the heels of last nightaposs announcement that shielding will be eased for .million vulnerable people in England. From July  shielding people can go out and meet up to five friends - andthey live alone, form a aposbubbleapos with another household. From August , the advice to shield ends completely. But Statutory Sick Pay and direct food parcels for the shielding will also end on August , prompting alarm. Thereaposs also anger at the failure to have a legal safeguard against people being forced back to work. Things you still canapost do from July  Venues that CANaposT reopen in England from July  Government sources said “it’s not felt that at this moment in time it’s possible” for those venues to reopen. Task forces will be set up to try to get these venues open in a safe way. Nightclubs Bowling alleys and skating rinks Indoor play areas including soft play Spas Nail bars Beauty salons Swimming pools Tattoo and piercing studios Massage parlours Water parks Indoor fitness and dance studios Gyms Conference centres, other than for people who already work there. You canapost go to the gym  Government sources said gyms remain shut because there is a “far greater risk of infection” due to people breathing harder and touching surfaces. Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden later insisted: Subject to public health, our aspiration is to reopen gyms  leisure facilities in mid-July. You canapost send your child to school  Only years R,  and  are allowed back to primary schools in England at the moment. The government wants all children back in September - but was forced to drop plans to do it earlier. Full plans for September are due to be announced next week. You canapost see a live theatre show  Theatres and concert halls can reopen in England from July  - with a catch. They can only reopen on the basis it’s not a live performance. Instead theatres and concert halls can screen past performances. Government sources said theatres have an issue with ensuring the actors themselves can move around the stage in a safe way. You canapost sing in church Worship will be allowed - but not full singing services due to the risk of spreading the virus. There will be further guidance about singing. You can get married, but not have a proper reception  Wedding services with up to  people will be allowed from July . But trips to indoor hospitality venues should still only be with one other household - in other words, the rules make wedding receptions almost impossible. This also applies to baptisms and Bar Mitzvahs and other “le cycle events”. The number of people allowed to celebrate a wedding will be increased at some point but it’s not known when or by how much. You canapost play cricket, football or rugby, except with your own household
